awd_titl_txt: SI2-SSI: Sustaining Globus Toolkit for the NSF Community (Sustain-GT)
awd_abstract_narration:
Science and engineering depend increasingly on the ability to collaborate and federate resources across distances. This observation holds whether a single investigator is accessing a remote computer, a small team is analyzing data from an engineering experiment, or an international collaboration is involved in a multi-decade project such as the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). Any distributed collaboration and resource federation system requires methods for authentication and authorization, data movement, and remote computation. Of the many solutions that have been proposed to these problems, the Globus Toolkit (GT) has proven the most persistently applicable across multiple fields, geographies, and project scales. GT resource gateway services and client libraries are used by tens of thousands of people every day to perform literally tens of millions of tasks at thousands of sites, enabling discovery across essentially every science and engineering discipline supported by the NSF. As new, innovative techniques and technologies for collaboration and scientific workflows are developed, and as new computing and instrument resources are added to the national cyberinfrastructure, these technologies and other improvements must be added and integrated into GT so that it can continue to provide an advanced and robust technology for solving scientific research problems.

The Sustain-GT project builds on past success to ensure that GT resource gateway services will continue to meet the challenges faced by NSF science and engineering communities. These challenges include: multiple-orders-of-magnitude increases in the volume of data generated, stored, and transmitted; much bigger computer systems and correspondingly larger and more complex computations; much faster networks; many more researchers, educators, and students engaged in data-intensive and computational research; and rapidly evolving commodity Web and Cloud computing environments. With the help of a new User Requirements Board, Sustain-GT will respond to community demands to evolve the GT resource gateway services with superior functionality, scalability, availability, reliability, and manageability. Sustain-GT will also provide the NSF community with high quality support and rapid-response bug fix services, as is required to sustain a heavily used, production system like GT.

por.por_cntn:
Science and engineering depend increasingly on the ability to collaborate and federate resources across distances. This basic observation is true whether we are talking about, for example, a single investigator accessing a remote computer, a small team analyzing data from an engineering experiment, or an international collaboration involved in a multi-decade project, such as the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). It is also true across scientific disciplines: access to large data and computational resources has long been critical to physical and geo-sciences, but in the past decade such access has also become fundamental to much of biological, social and economic research as well.


Effective distributed collaboration and resource federation involve a wide range of technical problems. However, a few fundamental issues arise repeatedly: authentication and authorization, data movement, and remote computation. Often, these different tasks must be done in concert, as when a high energy physics computation authenticates at multiple remote sites, moves data to those sites, and runs computations at those sites, or when a climate scientist authenticates and then downloads a large dataset.


These fundamental problems can be, and have been, solved in a variety of ways. However, one suite of software, Globus Toolkit (GT), has proven persistently applicable across many fields, geographies, and project scales. GT provides key resource gateway services that allow a resource provider to make local storage and compute resources available securely to remote clients through standard interfaces, regardless of local implementation choices such as what file systems and job schedulers are used locally on those resources. GT also provides libraries that are widely used by others to create new resource gateway services (e.g., Storage Resource Managers), and libraries that clients can use to access the resource gateway services from higher-level solutions such as workflow systems and science web portals (aka science gateways).


GT users include major international science projects (e.g., LHC, Earth System Grid: ESG, LIGO, Dark Energy Survey: DES), national cyberinfrastructures (e.g., Open Science Grid: OSG, XSEDE), regional and campus infrastructures (e.g., SURAgrid, UCLA), science gateways that enable community access to XSEDE, and individual research teams (e.g., Southern California Earthquake Center: SCEC). Collectively tens of thousands of researchers benefit from GT software on a daily basis.


More specifically, these tens of thousands of people have benefited from the GT team’s ability to solve, repeatedly, the new problems that arise as technologies and resource federation problems evolve. In a world of exponential technological change and rapid scientific innovation, cyberinfrastructure software must evolve constantly if it is to keep solving researcher problems. Data volumes and network capacities increase, requiring new protocols and optimizations in data movement software. New security architectures and security concerns emerge, requiring changes to authentication and authorization software. Resource managers add new features, and new resource types, such as clouds, become important. Standards emerge, that must be implemented and supported.


In summary, this project both provides immediate support to the large number of NSF science communities and researchers who depend on GT software in their daily work, and delivers the enhanced capabilities that these and other communities and researchers will require to address impending technology challenges.


Intellectual merit: This Sustain Globus Toolkit (GT) project has achieved its primary goal of maintaining and enhancing the GT in support of the large number of NSF science communities and researchers who depend on GT software in their daily work.  During the project, the number of operational GridFTP servers more than doubled to a peak of 37,000 and the data transferred over those servers more than tripled to a peak of 519 PetaBytes per year.

Broader impact: Globus Toolkit (GT) users include major international science projects (e.g., LHC, Earth System Grid: ESG, LIGO, Dark Energy Survey: DES), national cyberinfrastructures (e.g., Open Science Grid: OSG, XSEDE), regional and campus infrastructures (e.g., SURAgrid, UCLA), science gateways that enable community access to XSEDE, and individual research teams (e.g., Southern California Earthquake Center: SCEC). Collectively tens of thousands of researchers benefit from GT software on a daily basis.
